awd_titl_txt: Next-Generation NMR Crystallography Through Ab Initio Structure Refinement
awd_abstract_narration:
Gregory Beran of the University of California Riverside is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop new computational tools that will facilitate the determination of three-dimensional crystal structures via nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy.  Knowledge of molecular crystal structures is essential in pharmaceuticals and many other areas of chemistry.  Different crystal packing motifs ("polymorphs") of the same molecule can exhibit vastly different properties, and occurrences of undesirable polymorphs have caused major drug recalls and other serious problems for patients and pharmaceutical manufacturers.  NMR spectroscopy is increasingly used to determine crystal structures and characterize different polymorphs.  Translating the set of peaks present in an NMR spectrum into a three-dimensional crystal structure frequently involves trial-and-error computational modeling of potential structures to identify the structure whose predicted NMR spectrum best matches the experimentally observed one.  This project develops computational tools to circumvent this trial-and-error process and enable direct crystal structure refinement which can automatically solve for the crystal structure that produces the experimentally observed NMR spectrum.  These new tools will significantly improve the utility of NMR for solving crystal structures.  

Achieving these goals requires research advances in three areas. First, new computationally practical electronic structure methods for modeling the non-covalent interactions that govern crystal packing are being developed to enable identification of good initial crystal structures.  Second, because accurate predictions of the NMR chemical shifts for a given structure are essential to discriminating between correct and incorrect structural assignments when comparing predicted and observed spectra, models which predict NMR chemical shifts more reliably than widely used existing techniques are being developed.  Third, to enable direct NMR-driven crystal structure refinement, machine learning models that reproduce how changes in molecular conformation and crystal packing impact the chemical shifts are being developed.  Success will lead to greater ability to engineer molecular crystals with desired properties.  In addition, this award is supporting outreach activities at a local elementary school and production of online tools to educate new users about computational chemistry approaches.

por.por_cntn:
Knowledge of molecular crystal structures is essential in pharmaceuticals and many other areas of chemistry. Different crystal packing motifs (“polymorphs”) of the same molecule can exhibit vastly different properties, and occurrences of undesirable polymorphs have caused major drug recalls and other serious problems for patients and pharmaceutical manufacturers. The ability to predict these crystal polymorphs and their properties could help pharmaceutical companies identify important polymorphs during the formulation stage, contribute to solving or characterizing the crystal structures of unknown polymorphs, and facilitate the discovery of useful new organic materials by allowing researchers to understand how the properties vary under different experimental conditions.

Intellectual Merit

This project made substantial progress on all of its primary objectives. It identified a substantial, unappreciated weaknesses in how current quantum chemistry models being used to predict crystal structures describe changes in molecular conformation, and a new model was developed that addressed those issues. It established practical computational protocols for predicting crystal structures and properties at finite temperatures, in contrast to traditional models that neglect the effects of temperature. To facilitate crystal structure characterization, it developed improved strategies for predicting nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) chemical shifts in organic materials. That understanding was used to construct machine-learning (ML) models that achieve nearly the same accuracy as those models in a small fraction of the computer time/effort. These NMR models improve researchers’ ability to solve crystal structures via solid-state NMR experiments.

A number of chemical applications of the methods developed here were carried out as well. It was demonstrated of how pharmaceutical crystal structure predictions can be dramatically improved with the models described above. The work revealed that two reported high-pressure phases of carbon dioxide are actually the same phase,which alters our understanding of the high-pressure phase diagram. The first successful prediction of the temperature- and pressure-dependent phase behavior of a molecular crystal from first-principles (for methanol) was performed. In the future, such predictions could help researchers predict not only what crystal structures might exist, but also provide experimental researchers insights on the experimental conditions under which they could be made. Finally, an atomistic mechanism for how certain materials transform light into mechanical motion was established by combining our NMR prediction models with experimental work carried out by collaborators.

Broader Impacts:

Crystal structure prediction techniques are increasingly being incorporated as a complement to experimental solid-form screening by pharmaceutical companies, and the techniques developed here will help ensure the reliability of those predictions. Research resulting from this project was published in 22 peer-reviewed journal articles plus one additional tutorial article. Open-source software written during the project has been made available to the public at no cost. The PI gave both technical and pedagogical lectures at 16 different conferences/workshops/seminars.

Six graduate students participated in the project, four of whom have now graduated with their PhD degrees and have found employment in industry. The other two students are still enrolled and making good progress toward their PhD degrees.

The PI actively participated in educational/outreach activities aimed at helping students succeed at the university. Highlights include a set of pedagogical YouTube videos for quantum chemistry that have received over 191,000 views, lectures for faculty and graduate students aimed at improving the quality of instruction, and presentations to demographically diverse student groups regarding graduate school and faculty jobs in STEM fields. He also helped judge an elementary school science fair and gave a guest lecture on the intersection of computing and chemistry for middle school students.
